LEADERSHIP OF JOSEPH MOSES JOSHUA AND DEBORAH

Joseph

The early life of Joseph and his arrival in Egypt (Gen. 37: 1-28) 

Joseph was one of the twelve sons of Jacob, and the second son of Racheal, one of the Wives of Jacob. At the young age of seventeen he took up the task of shepherding his father’s flock With his brothers during which he brought an ill report of his brothers to their father. 

Jacob (Israel) loved Joseph more than any other of his children because he was the child of his old age and also made for him a long robe with sleeves. These probably made his brothers conclude that their father loved him more than them and as a result they hated him and could not speak peacefully to him. 

It happened that Joseph had a dream one day where they were binding sheaves in the field and behold his sheaf grew and stood upright to the extent that his brothers sheaves gathered round it and bowed down to his sheaf. 

His brothers were annoyed and said to him, “Are you indeed to reign over us? Or are you indeed to have dominion over us?” So, his brothers hated him the more for his dreams and for his words. Again, Joseph dreamt and told his brothers. In this one, the sun, the moon and eleven stars were bowing down for him. 

But after narrating this to his father and his brothers, his father rebuked him and said to him, “what is this dream that you have dreamed? Shall I and your mother and your brothers indeed come to bow ourselves on the ground before you?” His brothers were however jealous of him, but his father kept the saying in his mind. 

One day his brothers went to pasture their father’s flock near Shechem and Joseph was not with them. So, Jacob sent Joseph from the valley of Hebron to see how his brothers were fairing at Shechem and bring him words. When Joseph got to Shechem a man saw him while he was wandering and asked him what he was seeking, Joseph replied that he was seeking his brothers and further asked the man whether he saw them. The man then directed him to go to Dothan. So, Joseph went after his brothers and found them at Dothan. 

When they saw him from afar, they conspired to kill him, saying to one another, “Here comes this dreamer. Come now, let us kill him and throw him into one of the pits; then we shall say that a wide beast has devoured him, and we shall see what will come of his dreams.

Reuben was however at hand to deliver him out of the hands of his cruel brothers saying, “let us not take his life.” He further said to them, “Shed no blood; cast him into this pit here in the wilderness, but lay no hand upon him. He said this so that he will rescue him from them and restore him to his father. 

When Joseph came to his brothers, they removed his robe which was the robe with sleeves which their father made for him. They took him and cast him into an empty pit that has no water. 

 

Then they sat to eat and on looking up they saw a caravan of Ishmaelite coming from Gilead with their camels bearing gum, balm, and myrrh going down to Egypt. Judah one of Joseph’s brothers said to them, “What profit is it if we slay our brother and conceal his blood? Come, let us sell him to the Ishmaelite’s, and let not our hand be upon him, for he is our brother, our own flesh. "This advice was accepted by his brothers who drew Joseph up and lifted him from pit and then sold him to the Ishmaelites for twenty shekels of silver. The Ishmaelites took him down to Egypt where they later re-sold him to Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh.

Joseph’s brothers decided not to kill him 

because he

A. pleaded with them

B. was their brother and their flesh 

C. was loved by their father

D. was the first son of his mother.

Option B

Reference: Gen. 37: 26 – 27

 

Example

Joseph's brothers sold him to Ishmaelites at the cost of

A. twenty shekels of silver

B. twenty-five shekels of silver

D. forty shekels of silver

A

twenty shekels of silver

Gen 37:28 Then Midianite traders passed by; and they drew Joseph up and lifted him out of the pit, and sold him to the Ishmaelites for twenty shekels of silver; and they took Joseph to Egypt.

 

 

 

Joseph as the governor of Egypt (Gen, 41: 1- 57). 

After two years, while Joseph was in the prison, pharaoh had a dream in which he was standing by the Nile and there came out of the Nile seven cows sleek and fat feeding on the reed grass. And behold, seven other cows, gaunt and thin, came up out of the same Nile and stood by the other cows by the bank of the Nile. And the thin and the gaunt cows ate up the seven sleek and fat cows and still remained thin that no one would know that they had eaten them. 

Again, Pharaoh had another dream where he saw seven ears of grain, plump and good, that were growing on one stalk. Then another seven ears of the same grain sprouted out which were thin and blighted by the east wind. The thin ears swallowed the seven plump and full ears. 

The dreams troubled Pharaoh that he summoned all the magicians from Egypt and all its wise men and told them the dream he had, but none of the could interpret be it to him. It was then his chief butler (servant) who told him how he met a young Hebrew in custody when he offended the Pharaoh, who was a servant of the captain of the guard and how the young Hebrew servant interpreted their dreams to them and it came to pass. Immediately pharaoh sent for Joseph and he was brought out of the dungeon. 

After shaving and changing his clothes he was brought before the king and the king told him the dream which no one could interpret. Joseph said to him, “It is not in me; God will give pharaoh a favourable answer.” Having narrated the dreams to Joseph he said to Pharaoh, “The dream of Pharaoh is one; God has revealed to Pharaoh what he is about to do.” He explained that the seven good cows are seven years, and the seven good ears are seven years; the dream is one. 

The seven lean and gaunt cows that came up after them are seven years, and the seven empty ears blighted by the east wind are also seven years of famine. He further maintained that there will come seven years of great plenty throughout the land of Egypt, which will be followed by another seven years of famine. 

The famine will severe and consummate the land and the period of plenty will be forgotten in Egypt. He stressed that the doubling of the dream indicated that it was fixed by God and that God will shortly bring it to pass. 

On the remedy to avert the great famine Joseph advised Pharaoh to select a man who is discreet and wise and set him over the land of Egypt. He also advised him to appoint overseers over the land to take the fifth part of the produce of the land of Egypt during the seven plenteous years. And to gather all the food of these good years that are Coming and keep them in stock as reserve for the land against the seven years of famine which are to befall the land of Egypt. 

The proposal was good to pharaoh and his servants that he said to them, “Can we find such a man as this, in whom is the Spirit of God?” So pharaoh said to Joseph, “Since God has shown you all this, there is none so discreet and wise as you are; you shall be over my house, all my people shall order themselves as you command; only as regards the throne shall I be greater than you.” Pharaoh set him over all the land of Egypt, gave him his signet ring and arrayed him in garment of fine clothes with gold chain about his neck. Joseph was also given the second chariot of the king which by implication made him the second in command after Pharaoh. 

Moreover, Pharaoh said to Joseph, “I am Pharaoh, and without your consent no man shall lift up his hand or foot in all the land of Egypt." As a mark of his new office, Pharaoh gave him the name, Zaphenath-paneah,” and also gave him Asenath the daughter of Portiphera the priest of On in mage. Joseph was thirty years old when he entered the service of Pharaoh, the king of Egypt. 

During the seven years of plenteous harvest, Joseph was up to his task by gathering food and storing them up in every city from the fields around them. He stored food in great abundance like the sand of the sea, until he ceased to measure it, for it could not be measured. 

Before the year of famine, Joseph had two sons namely Manaseh, which means “God has made me forget all my hardship and all my father’s house” and Ephraim, meaning “For God has made me fruitful in the land of my affliction.” The seven years of plenty came to an end and the years of famine began just as Joseph said. 

There was famine in all the lands except in Egypt. When the whole land of Egypt was famished, they cried to Pharaoh for bread who sent them to Joseph with the order, “Go to Joseph; what he says to you, do.” So, when the famine spread all over the land, Joseph Opened all the storehouses, and sold to the Egyptians for the famine was severe and even people from all over the earth do go to Egypt for bread. 

 

Example

Joseph was made prime minister in Egypt because he

A. interpreted the dreams of Pharaoh’s servants in the prison

B. resisted the temptation by Potiphar’s wife

C. was a faithful and upright man

D. interpreted Pharaoh’s dream and counselled him on what to do.

Option D

 

Joseph reconciles with his brothers (Gen. 45:1-15) 

The famine that broke out affected the earth greatly that Egypt became a pilgrimage centre of its sort. The whole nations of the earth go the Egypt to buy their food. The children of Jacob were among the people who come to Egypt to buy food. 

In one of their trips when Joseph could not control himself again, he ordered all the people who were with him away and made himself known to his brothers who did not recognize him again and cried bitterly. 

When he asked them whether their father was still alive, they could not stand his presence probably for self guilt and this made them dismayed before Joseph. In order to clear their guilt, he made them to understand that it was God and not them who made him to come to Egypt for the preservation of life. 

Having made them understand his divine mission, he instructed his brothers to go back and bring his father and their entire household to Egypt where they shall live in the land of Goshen. Then he fell upon his brother Benjamin, wept and kissed all his brothers as a sign of love and true reconciliation and his brothers talked with him. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

MOSES AS A LEADER 

Social conditions of the Hebrews at the birth of Moses (Exodus 1) 

The number of the offspring of Jacob who moved down to Egypt where seventy. Following the death of Joseph, his brothers and all that generation, the descendants of Israel were fruitful and greatly increased; there came on the throne a new king in Egypt who did not know Joseph. 

The new king was disturbed by the increasing number of the Hebrews that he said to his people, “Behold, the people of Israel are too many and might for us. 

Come, let us deal shrewdly with them, lest they multiply, and if war befall us; they join our enemies and fight against us and escape from the land. ”As a result, taskmasters were set over the Hebrews to afflict them with heavy burdens. 

They were made to build for Pharaoh store-cities, Pithom' and Raamses. However, the more the Hebrews are Oppressed the more they multiply and spread, which the Egyptians to subject them to severe rigour and their lives were made bitter 'with hard services. This did not in any way affect their number as they kept increasing. 

In order to check the increasing number, ”Pharaoh instructed the two Hebrew midwives, Shiphrah and Puah to kilt upon the birth stool every male Child of the Hebrews, but to leave the male children, The two midwives who were God-fearing did not heed to the directives which made the king to summon them for cautioning. 

They replied the king that the Hebrew women have exceptional strength and deliver before they come unlike the Egyptain women. Because of the land gesture of the midwives God dealt well with them and gave them families. 

The final onslaught on the Hebrew was the command by the King that every son of the Hebrews should be cast into the Nile. It was during this offensive attack that Moses was born.

 

The early life and call of Moses (Exodus 2, 3)

Moses was born and being a male child, he was hidden by his mother for three months, but When she could no longer hide him, she put him in a basket and placed it among the reeds at the bank of river Nile. 

The daughter of Pharaoh came down to the river for her bathe in the Company of her maidens, she saw the basket and sent her maid to fetch it. 

When she opened it, she saw the child had pity on him and affirmed that the child was one of the Hebrews’ children. Immediately the sister of Moses who was hiding in the nearby offered to call a Hebrew woman to nurse the child, which the princess accepted. That was how Moses was brought up by his own mother and he came from the tribe of Levi. 

After nursing the child, the mother brought him back to the Pharaoh’s daughter who named him Moses, for she said, “Because I draw him out of the water.” One day when Moses had grown up, he was out to see the burden of his people when he saw an Egyptian beating a fellow Hebrew. 

He killed and hid the Egyptian in the sand. When he went out the next day, he saw two Hebrews struggling together and said to the man that did the wrong, “Why do you strike your fellow?” He answered, "Who made you a prince and a judge over us? Do you mean to kill me as you killed the Egyptian?" Moses was afraid and thought that Pharaoh would kill him if the news gets to him. 

Being uncomfortable he fled from Pharaoh to the land of Median where he sat down' by a well. There he helped the daughters of the priest of Median (Jethro) in watering their flock and delivered them from the hands of the shepherds. 

They reported this kind gesture to their father who instructed them to call Moses that he may eat bread in their house. Moses was contented to live with Jethro who gave him his daughter Zipporah in marriage. She gave birth to a son whom Moses called Gershom; for he said, “I have been a sojourner in a foreign land.

In those days, the people of Israel groaned under bondage in Egypt, they cried for help and their cry under bondage got to God who seeing their plight and knowing their condition remembered his covenant with Abraham, Isaac and Jacob their fathers. 

In response to the plight of the Israelites, God through his angel appeared to Moses at mount Horeb, the mountain of God where he was attending to the flock of his father-in-law in a flame of tire out of the midst of a bush. 

When Moses looked up, he saw a bush burning without consuming he said, “I will turn aside and see this great sight, why the bush is not burnt.” While making the move, God called him out of the bush, “Moses, Moses” And he said, “Here am I.” the voice then said, “Do not come near; put off your shoes from your feet, for the place on which you are standing is holy ground.” 

The voice again said, “I am the god of your father, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.” On hearing this, Moses hid his face for he was afraid to look at God. 

The Lord told Moses that he has seen the affliction of his people in the land of Egypt and that their cry has come up to him, and he is therefore set to bring them out of the land to a comfortable land that is flowing with milk and honey, to the place of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perinites, the Hivites and the Jebusites. 

He called on Moses that he might go to Pharaoh to bring the people of Israel out of Egypt. But Moses being afraid said to him, “Who am l that l should go to Pharaoh, and bring the sons of Israel out of Egypt?” 

God promised to be with him and that he shall serve God on the mountain as a sign when the people come out of Egypt.

 

Moses asked God what he shall say to the people if they should asked for his name, and God said to him, “I AM WHO l AM.” God further asked Moses to tell the people of Israel that the God of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob sent him to them. God directed Moses to meet the king with the elders of Israel to inform the king of their intention to go on a three-day journey into the wilderness to worship the Lord and offer sacrifice to their God. 

God however knew that the king will not grant the request unless compelled by a mighty hand. He then vowed to strike Egypt with so many wonders that at the end the people of Israel will be allowed to go. He promised to grant the Israelites favour in the sight of the Egyptians and advised them not to go empty but to go with their neighbors and belongings, so as to rob the Egyptians of great valuables. God equips and sends Moses to lead the Israelites out of Egypt.

Moses was still not convinced that the Israelites will believe or listen to him. In order to make the people believe Moses God first asked Moses what he was having in his hand and Moses responded “A rod.” He asked Moses to cast it on the ground and it turned to serpent and Moses fled from it. But the lord ordered him again to take it by the tail and it became rod in his hand. 

Secondly, God asked him to put his hand into his bosom and when he took it out, his hand was leprous, as white as snow. God again asked him to put his hand back into his bosom and when he did that his hand was restored to its normal state. 

God expressed assurance that the people will believe Moses but further maintained that if they fail to heed to the two signs that Moses should take some water from the Nile and pour it on the dry ground and it shall become blood upon the dry ground. 

Moses again complained of his lack of eloquence which God responded to by making Aaron his, spokesman. While Aaron was made his spokesman, Moses shall be to him as God. 

When Moses and Aaron met Pharaoh, the king of Egypt with the request to let the people go on three days journey into the wilderness to sacrifice to their Lord. A request which the king turned down with caution on Moses and Aaron to allow the people do their work. 

Following the unwillingness of Pharaoh to allow the people go but instead increased their burden, Moses turned to the Lord in disappointment and questioned why he sent him to speak to Pharaoh who has done evil to the people of Israel without the Lord delivering them. Moses was eighty years old and Aaron eighty-three years old when they spoke to Pharaoh.

Moses leads the people of Israel out of Egypt (Exodus 14: 1-31; 32: 1-14) 

Pharaoh finally allowed the Israelites to go after God had inflicted them with plagues, the last of it was the killing of the firstborn of both man and cattle. On their way out of Egypt, God instructed Moses to ask the people to encamp at Pi-ha-hi’roth. 

When Pharaoh heard that the people had fled, he regretted his action of letting the people go, as a result he set his army in pursuit of the Israelite just as the Lord hardened his heart. The Egyptians overtook them encamped at the sea by Pi-ha-hi’roth. 

When the people of Israel lifted up their eyes and saw Pharaoh drawing near, they were afraid Ind cried out to the Lord and blamed Moses for bringing them out into the wilderness to die, Insisting that it would have been better for them to die in Egypt while serving the Egyptians than to face the shameful death in the wilderness where there are no graves. 

Moses however said to them. “Fear not, stand firm, and see the salvation of the Lord, which he will work for you today; Moses asked God what he shall say to the people if they should asked for his name, and God said to him, “I AM WHO l AM.” God further asked Moses to tell the people of Israel that the God of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob sent him to them.

Secondly, God asked him to put his hand into his bosom and when he took it out, his hand was leprous, as white as snow. God again asked him to put his hand back into his bosom and when he did that his hand was restored to its normal state. 

God expressed assurance that the people will believe Moses but further maintained that if they fail to heed to the two signs that Moses should take some water from the Nile and pour it on the dry ground and it shall become blood upon the dry ground.

When Moses and Aaron met Pharaoh, the king of Egypt with the request to let the people go on three days journey into the wilderness to sacrifice to their Lord. 

A request which the king turned down with caution on Moses and Aaron to allow the people do their work. Following the unwillingness of Pharaoh to allow the people go but instead increased their burden, Moses turned to the Lord in disappointment and questioned why he sent him to speak to Pharaoh who has done evil to the people of Israel without the Lord delivering them. 

Moses was eighty years old and Aaron eighty-three years old when they spoke to Pharaoh. 

 

God adopted the following means to save the fleeing Israelites from the hands of the Egyptians who were closely pursuing them: 

1. The angel of the Lord went before the Israelites and behind them. 

2. A pillar of cloud from before them and stood behind them, thereby barricading the Israelites from the Egyptians. 

3. Moses was instructed by God to stretch out his hand over the sea and the Lord drove the sea back by a strong east wind, and the sea became dry land for the Israelite to pass. 

4. The wheels of the chariots were clogged by God thereby making it difficult for them to drive easily. This measure made the pursuing Egyptians confess that the LORD fights for the Israelites. 

5. The final onslaught on the Egyptians was when God instructed Moses to stretch out his hand over the sea which came back and drowned the Egyptians, their chariots and horsemen. 

The effect of the encounter was that having seen the marvelous works of the Lord, the Israelites feared the Lord; and believed in the Lord and in his servant Moses.

The Golden calf (Exodus 32: 1-14) 

When Moses delayed in coming down from the mountain, the people of Israel assembled themselves and demanded from Aaron for gods who shall go before them, since they no longer know what has become of Moses. 

Aaron then instructed them to take off the gold rings in the ears of their wives, sons and daughters and to bring them to him, which they did and Aaron fashioned it with a graving tool into a molten calf. He brought them to the people and said, “These are your gods, o Israel, who brought you up out of the land of Egypt!” 

Aaron also built an altar before the image and proclaimed a feast the next day in which the people offered burnt and peace offering, eating and drinking. 

The action was unacceptable to the Lord that he sent Moses down to see the evil which they have committed. 

He threatened to visit the people with his Wrath to consume them; but to make Moses 3 great nation. Moses however pleaded with the Lord reminding him the promise he made to their fathers to multiply their descendants and God pardoned them. He also reminded God that the Egyptians would say that he brought them out of Egypt to kill them in the wilderness. 

 

The spies sent out (Numbers 13: 1-33) 

From the wilderness of Paran, God asked Moses to send the leaders of each tribe to spy the land of Canaan. The men and their tribes include

1. Shammua, the son of Zaccur from the tribe of Reuben. 

2. Shaphat, the son of Hori from the tribe of Simeon 

3. Caleb the son of Jephunneh, from the tribe of Judah. 

4. Igal the son of Joseph, from the tribe 0f lssachax, 

5. Hoshea (Joshua) the son of Nun, from the tribe of Ephraim

6. Palti the son of Raphu, from the tribe of Benjamin. 

7. Gaddiel the son of Sodi, from the tribe of Zebulun. 

8. Gaddi the son of Susi, from the tribe of Joseph (Manasseh). 

9. Ammiel the son of Gamalli, from the tribe of Dan. 

10. Sethur the son of Michael, from the tribe of Asher. 

11. Nahbi the son of Vophsi from the tribe of Naphtali. 

12. Geuel the son of Machi, from the tribe of Gad. 

 

The mandates given to the twelve men include: 

1. To spy the land and find out the nature of her ihiiabitants. 

2. Find out whether the land is good or bad. 

3. Find out whether the cities that they dwell in are camps or strongholds. 

4. Find out whether the land is rich or poor. 

5. Find out whether there is wood in it or not. 

6. And finally to be courageous and bring some of the fruit of the land. 

The mission took them forty days and they returned to their people at the wilderness of Paran from where they were sent out, bringing back words and fruit of the land. The reports were that the land was flowing with milk and honey; that the inhabitants are strong and that the cities are fortified and very large, with the giant descendants of Anak. 

The people who dwelt in the land include the Amalekites, the Hittites, the Jebusites, the Amorites and the Canaanites. The impression the spies gave was that the inhabitants of the land were superior to the Israelites. 

However, Caleb encouraged the people to up into the land and occupy it giving them the impression that they can overcome its inhabitants. 

This did not go down well with the other men who discouraged the people with the evil report that the Israelites cannot stand the inhabitants of the land, likening the Israelites to grasshoppers before them.

Joshua and Caleb who were among the twelve spies rented their clothes and tried comforting the people of Israel by assuring them that the spied land is exceedingly good, and flowing with milk and honey. 

They also encouraged them not to rebel against the Lord and not to fear the inhabitants of the land for God will deliver them into their hands. This did not go down well with the people of Israel who planned to stone them. 

The Lord who was not happy with the people of Israel appeared to the people in glory and threatened to strike them for their unbelief and to visit them with pestilence and disinherit them, but to make Moses a greater and mightier nation. Moses in his interceding spirit passionately pleaded God on their behalf and God pardoned them.

JOSHUA AS A LEADER 

Why and how Joshua succeeded Moses (Numbers 13; Joshua 1)

Joshua the son of Nun was one of the twelve spies representing the tribe of Ephraim sent from the wilderness of Paran to spy the land of Canaan in order to find out its nature. He was originally known as Hoshea before Moses gave him the name Joshua. 

When the ten spies presented their frightening report to the congregation of Israel, it was Joshua and Caleb who comforted the Israelites with the message of hope of victory over the inhabitants of the land of Canaan, as already narrated. 

When Moses could no longer bear the task of leadership as a result of his old age, Joshua became a possible replacement. It was however noted that the Lord led him up into the mountain of Abarim to see the promised land and to die thereafter. 

Moses then prayed to God to appoint a man over the congregation to lead them in and out, that they may not be left like sheep without shepherd. Having made the request, the lord instructed Moses to take Joshua the son of Nun, a man in whom is the spirit and lay his hand upon him to commission him before Eleazar the priest and all the congregation. 

Moses was also directed by God to invest Joshua with some of his authority so that the people will obey him. After that Joshua will be made to stand before Eleazar the priest to inquire for him by the judgment of the Urim before the lord. Moses did as God directed him and thus Joshua became the leader of the Israelites after Moses. 

Following the death of Moses, God called on Joshua to take up the baton of leadership to lead the people of Israel to the promise land. God assured him that no man shall be able to stand before him all the days of his life and to be with him just as he was with Moses, and never to forsake or fail him.

He however encouraged him to be strong and courageous, and to be careful in keeping the law which Moses commanded him. God also encouraged him not to allow the book of the law depart from his mouth but to meditate on it day and night; for his success and prosperity depend on it. God finally assured him of his presence wherever he goes. He later died at the age of one hundred and ten.

DEBORAH AS A LEADER

The leadership of Deborah 

After the death of Joshua and Ehud one of the elders who lived after him, the people of Israel did what was evil in the sight of the Lord by going after other gods and the Lord sold them into the hands of Jabin the king of Canaan, who reigned in Hazor. 

The king of Canaan oppressed the people of Israel using Sisera, who was his army commander with nine hundred chariots of iron for twenty years. Following the oppression of the king, they cried out to the Lord for help and the lord came to their rescue through the instrumentality of a woman called Deborah At that time, Deborah, a prophetess and wife of Lappidoth was judging Israel. 

She summoned Barak the son of Abinoam who came from the tribe of Naphtali and instructed him as the lord directed her to gather his men at mount Tabor, taking with himself ten thousand men from the tribe of Naphtali and the tribe of Zebulun in a battle against Siserah, the commander of Jabin’s army by the river Kishon, with the promise of giving Jabin into his hand. 

Barak however declined going except Deborah goes with him. Deborah accepted going with him but pointed out to him that the lord will sell Siserah into the hand of a woman. 

When they got to the battle field, the Canaanites were defeated prompting Siserah to alight from his chariot and fled on foot to the house of Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, owing to the long-standing peace between Jabin the king and Heber the kenite. 

Jael lured him into her tent, covered him with rug. When Siserah asked for water, Jael opened a skin of milk, served him a drink and covered him again. Being so tired he slept off and Jael took a tent peg with hammer and nailed him on the ground leading to his death thereby fulfilling the prophecy of Deborah that the glow would go to a woman instead of Barak. 

As Barak was pursuing Siserah Jael went out to meet him calling inviting him to her tent to see Siserah whom he was seeking. Low and behold, Barak went in and saw Siserah laying dead, with the tent peg in his temple. Thus the lord granted victory to the Israelites and Jabin the king 0f Canaan was destroyed. g
